awd_titl_txt: EPRI: Vortex-Generator Arrays for Air-Cooled Condensers in Electric Power Generation
awd_abstract_narration:
1357992
Jacobi

This project is part of a jointly funded effort by the National Science Foundation and the Electric Power Research Institute to develop new electric power generation systems that use much less water than do current power generating plants. It is hard to overstate the importance of electric power generation and distribution to modern societies, and it is clear that growing power demands must be met within the constraints of limited resources and with reduced environmental impact. Water is a key national resource, and the water used in thermal-electric power plants represents 40% of the total annual draw from fresh-water supplies in the United States.  Almost all of this water is used for cooling steam after it passes through the steam-turbine generators in the power plant-this approach usually uses a cooling tower. An approach that cools the steam without using water in a cooling tower exists; it relies on so-called "Air-Cooled Condensers."  Unfortunately, this technology increases the cost of the power plant by up to five times, compared to a cooling-tower system. The cost of electricity would rise sharply, were power plants required to use current technology to save the cooling water. A new approach is needed to save water and hold down the price of electricity, and this project is aimed at providing the needed breakthrough. 

The main idea is to use small wing-like structures (called vortex generators) on a heat exchanger where steam is cooled by air. The vortex generators create a strong swirling flow in the air used to cool the steam. Through this project the potential of vortex generators to enhance the performance of air-cooled condensers will be evaluated, and the fundamental knowledge needed to use them effectively will be acquired. This new knowledge will lead to a new technology, an electric power generation system which provides reliable, inexpensive electricity and eliminates the need for drawing precious fresh water from our limited supplies to do so.

por.por_cntn:
An experimental and modeling study was performed for an air-cooled condenser for electric power generation. The study focused on a novel air-side design to significantly boost condenser capacity, coupled with condensate-management schemes for the steam-side flow to reduce pressure drop and further increase capacity.

On the airside, a method of repeatable vortex generation has been developed that has been proven to boost heat transfer coefficient. In addition, design guidelines for vortex generator winglets have been provided. Initial prototyping results have shown an increase in heat transfer coefficient but at some increase in air-side pressure drop. Knowledge gained from these prototypes has led to next-generation prototypes being developed that increase heat transfer coefficient further while lessening the pressure drop penalty.

On the steam side, visualization of the steam flow has provided a clear picture of the condenser physics. Both filmwise and dropwise condensation along the wall are drained by gravity and vapor shear along the tube, collecting at the bottom in a condensate river and flowing axially towards the condenser outlet. Increasing inclination angle has been shown to decrease the depth of this condensate river, with no other significant changes to the flow regime.

The result of the improved condensate drainage is to increase the condenser void fraction as the inclination angle is increased. This increases the flow area for vapor, which decreases vapor velocity and decreases the total pressure drop. The decrease was measured at 44% from 60o to 75o inclination. This effect is predicted to also be present for vacuum conditions, although the magnitude is expected to decrease to a 3% change in pressure drop.

The decrease in height of the condensate river also has a significant effect on the thermal performance of the condenser. The overall condenser thermal conductance has been shown to increase approximately by 0.08% for each degree increase in inclination angle. This change causes condenser capacity to increase by .048% for each degree increase in inclination angle. A total increase in capacity of 0.7% is found when increasing inclination angle from 60o to 75o.

The most important steam-side finding was in the final test, where airflow direction was reversed and condenser performance was compared for the air upflow vs. downflow configurations. Reversing air to flow downward has been shown to increase condenser capacity by 3.5% for a given inlet air-steam temperature difference and a horizontal condenser tube.

Overall, this project has shown significant improvements in the performance of the air-cooled condenser dor eclectric power generation, on both the air and steam sides. Further work is necessary on the airside to refine the VG prototypes. On the steam side, further research is necessary to validate the results at vacuum conditions. The outcome suggests the economic viability of generating electric power with and air-cooled condenser and significant reductions in consumed water in comparison to the use of a wet cooling tower.
